title: Quiz 6: Neonatal Infections
topicName: Unit Three Part One: Labour and Puerperium
description: Neonatal sepsis, congenital infections, and infection prevention strategies

questions.question: What is the most common cause of early-onset neonatal sepsis (within 72 hours)?
questions.explanation: Group B Streptococcus (GBS) is the most common cause of early-onset neonatal sepsis (within 72 hours). It is typically acquired from the mother during delivery, which is why intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended.
questions.hint: This organism is commonly found in the maternal genital tract.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of late-onset neonatal sepsis (after 72 hours)?
questions.explanation: Coagulase-negative staphylococci are the most common cause of late-onset neonatal sepsis (after 72 hours), particularly in preterm infants with indwelling catheters or prolonged hospitalization in NICU settings.
questions.hint: This organism is associated with hospital-acquired infections.

questions.question: Ophthalmia neonatorum can be caused by both gonorrhea and chlamydia.
questions.explanation: True. Ophthalmia neonatorum is a conjunctival infection of newborns that can be caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia trachomatis transmitted from the mother during birth. It can lead to blindness if untreated.
questions.hint: Both are sexually transmitted infections that can affect the newborn's eyes.

questions.question: Which of the following are risk factors for neonatal sepsis? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Risk factors for neonatal sepsis include PROM, prolonged labor, maternal fever during labor, and maternal GBS colonization. Elective cesarean section without labor or membrane rupture is not a significant risk factor.
questions.hint: Focus on factors that increase exposure to pathogens.

questions.question: Match each infection type with its causative organism:
questions.explanation: Early-onset sepsis = GBS, Late-onset sepsis = Coagulase-negative staphylococci, Ophthalmia neonatorum = Gonorrhea or Chlamydia, Neonatal tetanus = Clostridium tetani.
questions.hint: Consider the timing and source of each infection.

questions.question: The first-line antibiotic treatment for suspected early-onset neonatal sepsis is ___BLANK___ and ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: The first-line antibiotic treatment for suspected early-onset neonatal sepsis is ampicillin (to cover GBS and enterococci) plus gentamicin (to cover gram-negative organisms including E. coli).
questions.hint: Ampicillin covers gram-positive, gentamicin covers gram-negative.

questions.question: What is the prophylactic treatment for ophthalmia neonatorum?
questions.explanation: Prophylactic treatment for ophthalmia neonatorum consists of topical erythromycin or tetracycline ointment applied to both eyes shortly after birth to prevent gonococcal and chlamydial conjunctivitis.
questions.hint: This is applied directly to the eyes after birth.

questions.question: What is the most common congenital infection?
questions.explanation: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most common congenital infection, affecting approximately 0.5-1% of all live births. Most infected infants are asymptomatic at birth, but some develop hearing loss, developmental delay, or other complications.
questions.hint: This virus is a member of the herpes family.

questions.question: Neonatal tetanus can be prevented by clean cord care and maternal tetanus immunization.
questions.explanation: True. Neonatal tetanus is caused by contamination of the umbilical stump with Clostridium tetani spores. It can be prevented by maternal tetanus immunization and clean cord care practices during delivery.
questions.hint: This is a preventable disease with proper immunization.

questions.question: What does the TORCH acronym stand for in congenital infections?
acceptedAnswers: Toxoplasmosis, Other infections, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, Herpes
toxoplasmosis, other infections, rubella, cytomegalovirus, herpes
questions.explanation: The TORCH acronym describes congenital infections that can cause similar clinical findings: Toxoplasmosis, Other (syphilis, varicella, parvovirus), Rubella, Cytomegalovirus (CMV), and Herpes simplex virus.
questions.hint: Each letter represents a different congenital infection.
